segment.source: Basic 3D graphics for DirectX games
segment.target: Basic 3D graphics for DirectX games

segment.source: We show how to use DirectX programming to implement the fundamental concepts of 3D graphics.
segment.target: We show how to use DirectX programming to implement the fundamental concepts of 3D graphics.

segment.source: Basic 3D graphics for DirectX games
segment.target: Basic 3D graphics for DirectX games

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: We show how to use DirectX programming to implement the fundamental concepts of 3D graphics.
segment.target: We show how to use DirectX programming to implement the fundamental concepts of 3D graphics.

segment.source: Objective: Learn to program a 3D graphics app.
segment.target: Objective: Learn to program a 3D graphics app.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: We assume that you are familiar with C++.
segment.target: We assume that you are familiar with C++.

segment.source: You also need basic experience with graphics programming concepts.
segment.target: You also need basic experience with graphics programming concepts.

segment.source: Total time to complete: 30 minutes.
segment.target: Total time to complete: 30 minutes.

segment.source: Where to go from here
segment.target: Where to go from here

segment.source: Here, we talk about how to develop 3D graphics with DirectX and C++\\Cx.
segment.target: Here, we talk about how to develop 3D graphics with DirectX and C++\\Cx.

segment.source: This five-part tutorial introduces you to the Direct3D API and the concepts and code that are also used in many of the other DirectX samples.
segment.target: This five-part tutorial introduces you to the Direct3D API and the concepts and code that are also used in many of the other DirectX samples.

segment.source: These parts build upon each other, from configuring DirectX for your UWP C++ app to texturing primitives and adding effects.
segment.target: These parts build upon each other, from configuring DirectX for your UWP C++ app to texturing primitives and adding effects.

segment.source: Note This tutorial uses a right-handed coordinate system with column vectors.
segment.target: Note This tutorial uses a right-handed coordinate system with column vectors.

segment.source: Many DirectX samples and apps use a left-handed coordinate system with row vectors.
segment.target: Many DirectX samples and apps use a left-handed coordinate system with row vectors.

segment.source: For a more complete graphics math solution and one that supports a left-handed coordinate system with row vectors, consider using DirectXMath.
segment.target: For a more complete graphics math solution and one that supports a left-handed coordinate system with row vectors, consider using DirectXMath.

segment.source: For more info, see Using DirectXMath with Direct3D.
segment.target: For more info, see Using DirectXMath with Direct3D.

segment.source: We show you how to:
segment.target: We show you how to:

segment.source: Initialize Direct3D interfaces by using the Windows Runtime
segment.target: Initialize Direct3D interfaces by using the Windows Runtime

segment.source: Apply per-vertex shader operations
segment.target: Apply per-vertex shader operations

segment.source: Set up the geometry
segment.target: Set up the geometry

segment.source: Rasterize the scene (flattening the 3D scene to a 2D projection)
segment.target: Rasterize the scene (flattening the 3D scene to a 2D projection)

segment.source: Cull the hidden surfaces
segment.target: Cull the hidden surfaces

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
segment.target: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.

segment.source: Next, we create a Direct3D device, swap chain, and render-target view, and present the rendered image to the display.
segment.target: Next, we create a Direct3D device, swap chain, and render-target view, and present the rendered image to the display.

segment.source: Quickstart: setting up DirectX resources and displaying an image
segment.target: Quickstart: setting up DirectX resources and displaying an image
